thread.title: Firearm traders call for tougher penalties for gun thieves
thread.title_full: Firearm traders call for tougher penalties for gun thieves

author: Lisa Morrison
title: Firearm traders call for tougher penalties for gun thieves
text:
By Lisa Morrison, Mark Bennett, Andrew Collins and Christine Layton Posted February 02, 2017 19:42:31 Map: Albany 6330 
The president of the WA Firearm Traders Association (WAFTA) has called for mandatory prison terms for people convicted of stealing guns, after a spate of firearm thefts in regional WA. 
Police in the Great Southern towns Kojonup, Katanning, Narrogin and Albany recently formed a special taskforce to tackle an increase in gun thefts. 
WAFTA president Bevan Steele, who owns a gun shop in Narrogin and is a former police officer, said the penalties should be tougher. 
"They're getting a smack on the wrist," he said. 
"There's no different penalty for breaking into a house and stealing a gun [to] stealing a beer out of your fridge." 
A WA Police Media spokesman said police could charge offenders with stealing and possessing an unlicensed firearm. 
He said additional charges would depend on the circumstances of the offence. 
In WA, guns are required to be stored in approved cabinets under the Firearms Act 1973. 
Mr Steele said gun safes may attract rather than deter thieves. 
"The safes only slow the crooks down; they don't actually prevent anything," he said. 
"Law-abiding firearm owners are doing exactly what the law tells us. 
"We're pretty well putting an invitation sign on where the guns are. 
"We need to be looking at the root cause of the problem â€¦ punishing the guys that are committing these crimes." Police seize stolen weapons, drugs 
Great Southern Police Superintendent Dominic Wood said 77 guns had been stolen in 22 burglaries since August. 
In the past 100 days, 33 guns were stolen in the Katanning district alone. 
Police say some guns were being traded for drugs. 
Police seized stolen weapons and drugs during property raids and car searches as part of the taskforce operation. 
Superintendent Wood said local criminals with Perth connections were targeting rural farms. 
The operation follows a crackdown by police on the storage of firearms in December, which involved random inspections of firearm licence holders. 
Superintendent Wood called for gun owners to beef up security above the letter of the law. 
He said CCTV cameras could help police identify and charge gun thieves. 
"We have to try to deal with this because we know that firearms stolen from these sorts of premises end up in criminal hands," Superintendent Wood said. 
"That's the big, big concern for us." Are gun safes safe enough? 
'John' has an approved gun safe on his Pingrup property, about 50kms south of Lake Grace. 
He hides his guns instead because he believed it was safer. 
"I know it's against the law but I've got four high-powered rifles [and] those gun safes are so easy to get into," he said. 
"In 30 seconds I've had one of those open with a simple cordless angle grinder. 
"I'll always hide them in the same manner and I've never had a problem. If they can't find them, they can't steal them."
